Five Ways.quote: The existence of God can be proved in five ways: Motion, Causation, Contingency, Gradation, and Design. (Summa Theologica, I, Q.2, Art.3)

Natural Law.quote: The natural law is nothing else than the rational creature's participation in the eternal law. (Summa Theologica, I-II, Q.91, Art.2)

Faith and Reason.quote: Faith and reason are like two wings on which the human spirit rises to the contemplation of truth. (Summa Contra Gentiles, Book I, Ch.7)

Divine Nature.quote: God is pure act without any potentiality whatsoever. (Summa Theologica, I, Q.3, Art.1)

Human Nature.quote: Man is composed of a spiritual soul and physical matter, forming a single nature. (Summa Theologica, I, Q.75, Art.4)

Free Will.quote: Man has free will, otherwise counsels, exhortations, commands, prohibitions, rewards, and punishments would be in vain. (Summa Theologica, I, Q.83, Art.1)

Divine Providence.quote: God governs all things by His Providence, and nothing in the world happens by chance. (Summa Theologica, I, Q.22, Art.2)

Truth.quote: Truth is the adequation of thing and intellect. (De Veritate, Q.1, Art.1)

Being.quote: Existence is the most perfect of all things, for it is compared to all things as that by which they are made actual. (On Being and Essence, Ch.4)

Soul.quote: The soul is the first principle of life in those things which live. (Summa Theologica, I, Q.75, Art.1)

Virtue.quote: Virtue is that which makes its possessor good, and his work good likewise. (Summa Theologica, I-II, Q.55, Art.3)

Knowledge.quote: All our knowledge begins with the senses, proceeds then to understanding, and ends with reason. (Summa Theologica, I, Q.84, Art.7)

Justice.quote: Justice is a habit whereby a man renders to each one his due by a constant and perpetual will. (Summa Theologica, II-II, Q.58, Art.1)

Law.quote: Law is an ordinance of reason for the common good, made by him who has care of the community. (Summa Theologica, I-II, Q.90, Art.4)

Grace.quote: Grace does not destroy nature but perfects it. (Summa Theologica, I, Q.1, Art.8)

Evil.quote: Evil is a privation of the good that ought to be present. (Summa Theologica, I, Q.48, Art.1)

Happiness.quote: The ultimate end of human life is happiness or beatitude. (Summa Theologica, I-II, Q.1, Art.8)

Essence and Existence.quote: In God alone, essence and existence are identical. (On Being and Essence, Ch.4)

Angels.quote: Angels are pure forms, subsisting without matter. (Summa Theologica, I, Q.50, Art.2)

Creation.quote: Creation is not a change, but the very dependency of created being on the principle from which it is set up. (Summa Theologica, I, Q.45, Art.3)

Natural Theology.quote: Sacred doctrine is a science because it proceeds from principles known by the light of a higher science, namely, the science of God. (Summa Theologica, I, Q.1, Art.2)

Moral Action.quote: The morality of an act is determined by three things: its object, its end, and its circumstances. (Summa Theologica, I-II, Q.18, Art.4)

Divine Simplicity.quote: God is absolutely simple, admitting of no composition whatsoever. (Summa Theologica, I, Q.3, Art.7)

Human Intellect.quote: The human intellect is the lowest of intellectual beings. (Summa Theologica, I, Q.76, Art.5)

Divine Law.quote: Divine law was necessary for the direction of human life. (Summa Theologica, I-II, Q.91, Art.4)

Political Theory.quote: Man is by nature a political animal, as the Philosopher says. (Commentary on Aristotle's Politics)

Sacraments.quote: A sacrament is a sign of a sacred thing in so far as it sanctifies men. (Summa Theologica, III, Q.60, Art.2)

Metaphysics.quote: Metaphysics deals with being as being. (Commentary on Aristotle's Metaphysics)

Divine Attributes.quote: God is not only His own essence but also His own existence. (Summa Theologica, I, Q.3, Art.4)

Natural Rights.quote: Every man has by nature the right to what is necessary for his preservation. (Summa Theologica, II-II, Q.66, Art.7)
